questions.text: A resident doctor got a scratch while performing a procedure and later his blood clotted. For investigation purposes, he collected the fluid that oozed out from the clot. Which things he is not likely to find in this fluid:
questions.solution:
The fluid that is being referred to here is serum. It contains no clotting factors and fibrinogen. Its basically plasma without these factors. It also contains no cellular formed elements of the blood.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition pg.111)

questions.text:
A 47 y/o female came to the clinic with complaints of itching over her skin. On clinical examination, her primary care physician noted a yellowish discoloration of the sclera and also noted some tenderness on the right hypochondrium. The doctor ordered a report for her serum bilirubin and the following was noted:
Serum bilirubin: 7.6mg/dl and most of it was of the conjugated type. What did the doctor suspect:
questions.solution:
The case points towards obstructive jaundice. In this most of the bilirubin is of the conjugated type and since there is obstruction to the flow of bile, there is less formation of stercobilinogen from the bilirubin and hence the stools appear pale in color.

In hemolytic anemia the maximum bilirubin is of the un-conjugated type and the stools are dark colored due to increased stercobilinogen formation.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition pg.129)

questions.text:
A 64 y/o male presented to the clinic with the chief complaint of fever and excessive weight loss over the past 2 months. He says that he lost 9 kg in just last 15 days. The doctor ordered a complete blood count and the following was obtained:
RBC COUNT: 5 million/cu mm
PLATELETS: 2.4lacs/micro litre
HEMOGLOBIN: 10gms/dl
TLC: 80,520 cells/micro litre
NEUTRO: 26,000 cells/micro litre
EOSINO: 2,400 cells/micro litre
MONO: 2,120 cells/micro litre
LYMPHO: 50,000 cells/micro litre
The lymphocytes were of immature type as seen on the peripheral blood smear. What should the doctor suspect:
questions.solution:
Types of Leukemia. Leukemias are divided into two general types: lymphocytic leukemias and myelogenous leukemias. The lymphocytic leukemias are caused by cancerous production of lymphoid cells, usually beginning in a lymph node or other lymphocytic tissue and spreading to other areas of the body. The second type of leukemia, myelogenous leukemia, begins by cancerous production of young myelogenous cells in the bone marrow and then spreads throughout the body so that white blood cells are produced in many extramedullary tissues-especially in the lymph nodes, spleen, and liver. Usually, the more undifferentiated the cell, the more acute is the leukemia, often leading to death within a few months if untreated. With some of the more differentiated cells, the process can be chronic, sometimes developing slowly over 10 to 20 years. Leukemic cells, especially the very undifferentiated cells, are usually nonfunctional for providing the normal protection against infection.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.431)

questions.text: The part of the reticuloendothelial system present in the liver and lungs is:
questions.solution:
the Reticuloendothelial system also called the monocyte macrophage system includes the resident tissue macrophages and the blood monocytes. Option B and C are incorrect since peyer’s patches are found in the intestine and histiocytes are found in the skin. Kupffer cells and dust cells are found in liver and lungs respectively and hence option A is right.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition pg.135)

questions.text: A patient had recently suffered from myocardial infarction and was on anticoagulant therapy instituted with warfarin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug and what INR will the patient have while on this therapy:
questions.solution:
When a coumarin, such as warfarin, is given to a patient, the amounts of active prothrombin and Factors VII, IX, and X, all formed by the liver, begin to fall. Warfarin causes this effect by inhibiting the enzyme, vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1 (VKOR c1). As discussed previously, this enzyme converts the inactive, oxidized form of vitamin K to its active, reduced form. By inhibiting VKOR c1, warfarin decreases the available active form of vitamin K in the tissues. When this occurs, the coagulation factors are no longer carboxylated and are biologically inactive. Over several days the body stores of the active coagulation factors degrade and are replaced by inactive factors. Although the coagulation factors continue to be produced, they have greatly decreased coagulant activity. The international normalized ratio (INR) was devised as a way to standardize measurements of prothrombin time. For each batch of tissue factor, the manufacturer assigns an international sensitivity index (ISI), which indicates the activity of the tissue factor with a standardized sample. The ISI usually varies between 1.0 and 2.0. The INR is the ratio of the person’s prothrombin time to a normal control sample raised to the power of the ISI:

The normal range for INR in a healthy person is 0.9 to 1.3. A high INR level (e.g., 4 or 5) indicates a high risk of bleeding, whereas a low INR (e.g., 0.5) suggests that there is a chance of having a clot. Patients on warfarin therapy usually have an INR of 2.0 to 3.0.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.461).

choices.text: massive coagulation in the vascular system

questions.text: A 45y/o male patient was admitted in the hospital and had history of excessive alcohol intake. The liver function test of the patient had shown raised levels of AST and ALT. A consultant doctor ordered that this patient was to be given 500 ml of citrated blood due to low cell counts. The resident doctor was carrying out this order and was called by the nurse to see other patients waiting since morning. To attend to the waiting patients, the resident increased the rate of transfusion. What is likely to happen to this patient?
questions.solution:
After injection, the citrate ion is removed from the blood within a few minutes by the liver and is polymerized into glucose or metabolized directly for energy. Consequently, 500 milliliters of blood that has been rendered incoagulable by citrate can ordinarily be transfused into a recipient within a few minutes without dire consequences. But if the liver is damaged or if large quantities of citrated blood or plasma are given too rapidly (within fractions of a minute), the citrate ion may not be removed quickly enough, and the citrate can, under these conditions, greatly depress the level of calcium ion in the blood (hence Option B is incorrect), which can result in tetany and convulsive death. Due to reduced calcium ion massive coagulation cannot occur in the body and hence Option C is incorrect.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.460).

choices.text: factor that promotes fibrosis and wound healing

questions.text: Alpha granules of the platelets contain all of the following except:
questions.solution:
platelets contain all of the following. The factor that helps in fibrosis and wound healing is PDGF. Thrombospondin helps in stabilization of the plug. And platelet factor 4 acts as a procoagulant.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south east asia edition page.152, box26-1).

questions.text: During the development of the embryo, which cells migrate to the developing tetes to form the immature germ cells:
questions.solution:
During formation of the embryo, the primordial germ cells migrate into the testes and become immature germ cells called spermatogonia, which lie in two or

three layers of the inner surfaces of the seminiferous tubules (a cross section of one is shown in Figure 80-2A). The spermatogonia begin to undergo mitotic division, beginning at puberty, and continually proliferate and differentiate through definite stages of development to form sperm, as shown in Figure 80-2B.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.973).

questions.text: Estrogen formed from testosterone by the sertoli cells in response to stimulation by which hormone:
questions.solution:
Estrogens, formed from testosterone by the Sertoli cells when they are stimulated by follicle-stimulating hormone, are probably also essential for spermiogenesis. LH hormone helps in the production of testosterone by the leydig cells and GnRH or gonadotropin releasing hormone helps in the production of FSH and LH from the anterior pituitary gland. Hence option B and C are incorrect.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.975).

questions.text: Which gene causes the genital ridge to be differentiated into testosterone producing cells and testes:
questions.solution:
Testosterone begins to be elaborated by the male fetal testes at about the seventh week of embryonic life. Indeed, one of the major functional differences between the female and the male sex chromosome is that the male chromosome has the SRY (sex-determining region Y) gene that encodes a protein called the testis determining factor (also called the SRY protein). The SRY protein initiates a cascade of gene activations that cause the genital ridge cells to differentiate into cells that secrete testosterone and eventually become the testes, whereas the female chromosome cause this ridge to differentiate into cells that secrete estrogens. CFTR gene is implicated in cystic fibrosis and Dystrophin gene codes for muscle component called as dystrophin.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.981).

questions.text: A 26 y/o female visited her gynecologist with the complaints that she was not able to conceive a child even after having normal menstrual cycle. The doctor examined her next menses and it was found that it contained no ovum. This condition is called as:
questions.solution:
anovulatory menstrual cycle is the one in which normal menstrual cycle occurs without ovulation. Amenorrhea is complete absence of menses. And menarche is time of first menstrual cycle. Hence the option A and C are incorrect.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.987).

questions.text: This picture presents the process of production of principal female hormone. Which are the molecules labeled A and B:
questions.solution:
Synthesis of the Estrogens and Progestins. Note from the chemical formulas of the estrogens and progesterone in Figure 81-6 that they are all steroids. They are synthesized in the ovaries mainly from cholesterol derived from the blood but also to a slight extent from acetyl coenzyme A, multiple molecules of which can combine to form the appropriate steroid nucleus. During synthesis, mainly progesterone and androgens (testosterone and androstenedione) are synthesized first; then, during the follicular phase of the ovarian cycle, before these two initial hormones can leave the ovaries, almost all the androgens and much of the progesterone are converted into estrogens by the enzyme aromatase in the granulosa cells. Because the theca cells lack the aromatase, they cannot convert androgens to estrogens. However, androgens diffuse out of the theca cells into the adjacent granulosa cells, where they are converted to estrogens by aromatase, the activity of which is stimulated by FSH (Figure 81-7). During the luteal phase of the cycle, far too much progesterone is formed for all of it to be converted, which accounts for the large secretion of progesterone into the circulating blood at this time. Also, about one-fifteenth as much testosterone is secreted into the plasma of the female by the ovaries as is secreted into the plasma of the male by the testes.

Option D is incorrect as aldosterone is implied in regulating sodium and water balance of the body and option B is incorrect since retinol is involved in the visual cycle of the eye.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.992).

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Braxton-Hicks contractions:
questions.solution:
Braxton-Hicks contraction are slow, rhythmic and episodic contractions that later during the course of pregnancy become intense followed by dilation of birth canal and this parturition. This process is called as labor and the final contractions that cause parturition are called as labor contractions.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition page.692).

questions.text: During a thyroid surgery, inadvertent removal of a surrounding tissue occurred, following which, Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign were present in the patient. What is the most likely tissue removed?
questions.solution:
Option (3) is correct because, occasionally, inadvertent parathyroidectomy occurs during thyroid surgery. After parathyroidectomy, there is a steady decline in the plasma Ca2+ level. Signs of neuromuscular hyperexcitability appear, followed by full-blown hypocalcaemia tetany.Plasma phosphate levels usually rise as the plasma Ca2+ level falls. Signs of tetany in humans include Chvostek sign, a quick contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles elicited by tapping over the facial nerve at the angle of the jaw, and Trousseau sign, a spasm of the muscles of the upper extremity that causes flexion of the wrist and thumb with extension of the fingers.

Removal of isthmus of thyroid or superior belly of omohyoid does not produce tetany. Hence, these are incorrect.]

[Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.380;

choices.text: Addison's disease; Increased production of melanin
Addison's disease; Increased production of ACTH
Cushing's disease; Increased production of melanin
Cushing's disease; Increased production of ACTH

questions.text: A 34 years old female complaints of weakness, loss of appetite, reduced weight, nausea and vomiting with a past history of recurrent respiratory infections. Her skin has numerous hyperpigmented patches. Lab investigations revealed hyponatremia, hyperkalaemia, and mild acidosis, decreased extracellular fluid volume.red blood cell concentration markedly risen, cardiac output and low blood pressure. What is the patient most likely suffering from and what is the cause of hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
The symptoms especially hyperpigmentation of skin are indicative towards Addison’s disease. Lab investigations furthermore confirm this diagnosis of Addison’s disease.

In Addison’s disease, the increased amounts of ACTH cause most of the pigmenting effect because they can stimulate formation of melanin by the melanocytes in the same way that MSH does.

In Cushing’s disease, about 80 percent of patients have hypertension, with edematous appearance of the face, acne and hirsutism (excess growth of facial hair). The appearance of the face is described as a “moon face”. So, cushing’s disease is an incorrect diagnosis of this case.]

[Ref:- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 12th Edition; Page No. 934

choices.text: loss-of-function mutations resulting in growth hormone insensitivity or Laron dwarfism.
short stature due to gonadal dysgenesis
psychosocial dwarfism or the Kaspar Hauser syndrome

questions.text: A 10 years old boy was bought to the OPD by his parents complaining about the short stature of the boy in comparison to the other children of his age. This family belongs to a higher socio-economic group and the boy is looked after properly. Investigation revealed normal plasma growth levels and normal thyroid function tests. Karyotyping was done and no chromosomal abnormalities were observed. What could be the cause behind this boy's short stature?
questions.solution:
In a group of dwarfed children, the plasma growth hormone concentration is normal or elevated but their growth hormone receptors are unresponsive as a result of loss-of-function mutations. The resulting condition is known as growth hormone insensitivity or Laron dwarfism.

Short stature is also part of the syndrome of gonadal dysgenesis seen in patients who have an XO chromosomal pattern instead of an XX or XY pattern.

Chronic abuse and neglect can also cause dwarfism in children, independent of malnutrition. This condition is known as psychosocial dwarfism or the Kaspar Hauser syndrome, named for the patient with the first reported case.

Achondroplasia, the most common form of dwarfism in humans, is characterized by short limbs with a normal trunk. It is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the gene that codes for fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3). This member of the fibroblast growth receptor family is normally expressed in cartilage and the brain.

So, among the given options, Option (1) is the most accurate in this given case.]

[Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.332; CLINICAL BOX 18-2;

questions.text: A 3 years old child, belonging to lower socio-economic status, presented to the OPD with short stature and mental retardation. Lab investigations revealed high plasma cholesterol levels, and low BMR.The mother of the child was found to be hypothyroid when she was pregnant with this child.. No chromosomal abnormalities were found on investigation. What is the child most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Turner’s syndrome- occurs due to chromosomal abnormality, which is absent in this child. So, this is incorrect option.

Dwarfism- this child is not only suffering from dwarfism, but also with mental retardation so this is also not a correct option.

Neurological disorder- it may cause mental retardation, but the other symptoms of this child and lab investigations donot support this diagnosis.

Cretinism- The symptoms and lab investigations of this child are suggestive of hypothyroidism. Also, themother of the child was found to be hypothyroid when she was pregnant. Al these findings point towards cretinism. Hence, this is the correct option.

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.344

questions.text: A 30 years old obese female was recently diagnosed to be suffering from polycystic ovary disease. What among the following is she at the highest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Type II diabetes, also called non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM), is caused by decreased sensitivity of target tissues to the metabolic effect of insulin. This reduced sensitivity to insulin is often called insulin resistance. Obesity and polycystic ovary disease are causes of Insulin Resistance. Hence, option (2) is most likely to develop.

Type I diabetes, also called insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM), is caused by lack of insulin secretion. It usually develops <20 years of age.

Hyperthyroidism - occurs due to increased thyroid hormone levels (T3 and T4) and, it leads to weight loss in the patient. This is contraindicatory to the presenting condition of the patient.

Hence, among the given options, Option (2) is most accurate.

Ref:- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 12th Edition; Page No. 952; Table 78-2

questions.text: A 45 years old male working in a factory related with silica dust since last 20 years, presented to the OPD with shortness of breath, loss of appetite, chest pain. On examination, clubbing was present. Which curve would you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from silicosis, a type of pulmonary fibrosis. Pulmonary fibrosis is a progressive restrictive airway disease in which there is stiffening and scarring of the lung. The pressure-volume curve of the total respiratory system is shifted downward and to the right (compliance is decreased) by pulmonary edema and interstitial pulmonary fibrosis. Hence, option (2) is correct.

The curve is shifted upward and to the left (compliance is increased) in emphysema. Hence, option (1) is incorrect.

The pressure- volume curve does not remain normal in pulmonary fibrosis, hence option (3) is incorrect.

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.630 and 631; Fig 34-11;

choices.text: Surface tension in the lungs of these infants is high, and the alveoli are collapsed in many areas (atelectasis)

questions.text: A prematurely born infant is most likely to suffer from infant respiratory distress syndrome, what is the most likely cause of it?
questions.solution:
Surfactant deficiency is an important cause of infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS, also known as hyaline membrane disease), the serious pulmonary disease that develops in infants born before their surfactant system is functional. Surface tension in the lungs of these infants is high, and the alveoli are collapsed in many areas (atelectasis).

An additional factor in IRDS is retention of fluid in the lungs. During fetal life, Cl- is secreted with fluid by the pulmonary epithelial cells. At birth, there is a shift to Na+ absorption by these cells via the epithelial Na+ channels (ENaCs), and fluid is absorbed with the Na+. Prolonged immaturity of the ENaCs contributes to the pulmonary abnormalities in IRDS.

Overproduction/dysregulation of surfactant proteins can also lead to respiratory distress and is the cause of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP).

Treatment of IRDS is commonly done with surfactant replacement therapy.

Hence, all of the given potions are correct.

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.632;

choices.text: The blood should have not been stored in acid-citrate-dextrose solution.
The blood should have been stored in citrate-phosphate-dextrose solution
The blood should be negative for HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C.

questions.text: A 25 years old female anaemic patient recently suffered a road traffic accident, following which she needed urgent blood supply? What will be the precautions you will look for before the transfusion?
questions.solution:
Red cell 2,3-DPG concentration is increased in anemia and in a variety of diseases in which there is chronic hypoxia.This facilitates the delivery of O2 to the tissues by raising the Po2 at which O2 is released in peripheral capillaries. In banked blood that is stored, the 2,3-DPG level falls and the ability of this blood to release O2 to the tissues is reduced. This decrease, which obviously limits the benefit of the blood if it is transfused into a hypoxic patient, is less if the blood is stored in citrate-phosphate-dextrose solution rather than the usual acid-citrate-dextrose solution.

Also, the blood should be tested for HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and other diseases to prevent blood borne diseases.

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.642;

choices.text: Yes, he will suffer from hypoxia; histotoxic hypoxia
Yes, he will suffer from hypoxia; Hypoperfusion hypoxia
Yes, he will suffer from hypoxia; anaemic hypoxia
No, he will not suffer from hypoxia

questions.text: A 30 years old male patient came in contact with a poisonous gas following an accidental gas leakage from a factory. He developed,headache,nausea and difficulty in breathing suggestive of hypoxia. His skin and nails developed cherry red discolouration.Will he suffer from hypoxia? If yes, which type of hypoxia is he most likely to suffer?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of the patient is suggestive towards CO poisoning.

The symptoms of CO poisoning are those of any type of hypoxia, especially headache and nausea, but there is little stimulation of respiration, since in the arterial blood, PO2 remains normal and the carotid and aortic chemoreceptors are not stimulated. The cherry-red color of COHb is visible in the skin, nailbeds, and mucous membranes.

Hypoxia due to inhibition of tissue oxidative processes is most commonly the result of cyanide poisoning. Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase.

Thus, option (1) is correct.

Hypoxia due to anemia is called as anaemic hypoxia.

Hypoperfusion hypoxia, or stagnant hypoxia, is due to slow circulation and is a problem in organs such as the kidneys and heart during shock. It is not the type of hypoxia seen in cyanide poisoning.

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No. 621;

choices.text: increased risk of fracture of the vertebrae

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to happen when an aviator is subjected to negative G?
questions.solution:
Option(1) -Negative ‘g’ causes increased cardiac output

Option(2) - In Negative G, forces can be so great (−20G, for instance) and centrifugation of the blood into the head is so great that the cerebral blood pressure reaches 300 to 400mm Hg. Since, the eyes are not protected by the cranium, intense hyperemia occurs in them during strong negative G. As a result, the eyes often become temporarily blinded with “red-out.”

Option(3) - Acceleration greater than 4 to 6G causes “blackout” of vision within a few seconds and unconsciousness shortly thereafter. If this great degree of acceleration is continued, the person will die.

Negative G causes “Red-out”

Option(4) --extremely high acceleratory forces for even a fraction of a second can fracture the vertebrae. This happens in Positive g, not in negative G.

Hence, the correct option is (2)

Ref:- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 12th Edition; Page No. 531,

choices.text: REMOVAL OF ISCHEMIC KIDNEY OR ARTERIAL CONSTRICTION CURES DOES NOT CURES THE HYPERTENSION
ONE CLIP ONE KIDNEY GOLDBLATT HYPERTENSION ASSOCIATED WITH DECREASED PLASMA RENIN ACTIVITY
THERE IS PROMPT INCREASE IN RENIN SECRETION LEADING TO SUSTAINED HYPERTENSION
TREATMENT CANNOT BE GIVEN WITH ACE INHIBIOTORS OR LOSARTN

questions.text: A 50 YEAR OLD MALE PATIENT COMES TO OPD WITH COMPLAINTS OF HEADACHE, SOMETIMES PALPITATION. THE PATIENT IS DIAGNOSED OF HAVING HYPERTENSION. ON INVESTIGATION THE PATIENT HAS CONSTRICTION IN ONE RENAL ARTERY. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS THE TRUE STATEMENT
questions.solution:
SINCE THERE IS CONSTRICTION OF ARTERY IN KIDNEY THEIR IS DECREASED BLOOD SUPPLY WHICH THE BODY TRIES TO COMPENSATE WITH INCREASE IN RELEASE OF RENIN

THE TRUE STATEMENT FOR OTHER OPTION IS AS FOLLOWS

A) REMOVAL OF ISCHEMIC KIDNEY OR ARTERIAL CONSTRICTION CURES DOES CURES THE HYPERTENSION IF NOT PERSISTED TOO LONG

B)ONE CLIP ONE KIDNEY GOLDBLATT HYPERTENSION ASSOCIATED WITH NORMAL PLASMA RENIN ACTIVITY

D)TREATMENT CAN BE GIVEN WITH ACE INHIBIOTORS OR LOSARTN

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG704

choices.text: THE PERMEABILITY OF THE GLOMERULAR CAPPILARIES IS DECREASED
THE MOST COMMONLY SEEN PROTEIN IN PROTEINURIA IS ALBUMIN
IN NEPHROSIS AMOUNT OF PROTEIN LOSS EXCEEDS THE RATE AT WHICH THE LIVER CAN SYNTHESIZE PLASMA PROTEINS
EDEMA OCCURS IN PATIENTS DUE REDUCE ONCOTIC PRESSURE AND PLASMA VOLUME DECLINES

questions.text: A PATIENT IS PRESENTED WITH COMPLAINTS DURING URINATION AS WELL AS ACUMMULATION OF FLUID IN TISSUES. ON INVESTIGATION PATIENT HAS PRESENCE OF PROTEIN IN URINE. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS FALSE
questions.solution:
THE PERMEABILITY OF GLOMERULAR CAPPILARIESIS INCREASED AND NOT DECREASED. WHICH LEAD TO PRESENCE OF PROTIEN IN URINE.LOSS OF PROTEINS LEADS TO REDUCTION OF THE ONCOTIC PRESSURE THE PLASMA VOLUME AS WELL DECREASES.

ALL OTHER STAEMNTS ARE TRUE

choices.text: DUE TO INTERRUPTION OF AFFERENT NERVES FROM BLADDER
DUE TO INTERRUPTION OF BOTH AFFERENT AND EFFERENT NERVES
DUE TO INTERRUPTION OF FACILITATORY AND INHIBITORY PATHWAY

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING ABNORMALITY IN MICTURATION IS NOT DUE TO NEURAL LESION
questions.solution:
OPTION A, B AND C ARE THE REASON FOR ABNORMALITY IN MICTURATION DUE TO NEURAL LESION

WHEREAS ABNORMALITY IN MICTURATION IS DUE TO THE INCREASED SIZE AND OBSRRUCTION OF THE PATHWAY FOR MICTURATION IN PROSTRATE ENLARGEMENT

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 693

choices.text: THE NEUROTOXINS ACT BY ENHANCING THE NEUROTRANSMITTER RELEASE IN CNS
THE ACTIVITY OFMOTOR NEURONS IS MARKEDLY DECREASED
THIS CONDITION IS CAUSED BY CLOSTRIDIUM TETANI
THE CHARACTERISTIC LOCK JAW IS DUE TO FLACCID PARALYSIS

questions.text: A PATIENT COMES TO THE OPD WITH COMPLAINS OF DIFFICULTY IN OPENING MOUTH AND HAVE LOCK JAW. THE PATIENT HAD HISTORY OF ROAD ACCIDENT 9 YEARS AGO AND DIDN'T TOOK ANY VACCINE FOR TH SAME. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS TRUE IN THIS SITUATION
questions.solution:
THE TRUE STATEMENT FOR OTHER OPTION IS AS FOLOWS

A)THE NEUROTOXINS ACT BY PREVENTING THE RELEASE OF NEUROTRANSMITTER IN CNS

B)THE ACTIVITY OFMOTOR NEURONS IS MARKEDLY INCREASED

D)THE CHARACTERISTIC LOCK JAW IS DUE TO SPASTIC PARALYSIS

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 125

choices.text: PHANTOM LIMB PAIN; THE ACCEPTED THEORY IS BRAIN CAN RECOGNIZE IF SENSORY INPUT IS CUT OFF
THALAMIC PAIN SYNDROME; SUCH SENSATION OCCUR AFTER REMOVAL OF BODY PARTS OTHER THAN LIMBS TOO
PHANTOM LIMB PAIN; SPINAL CORD STIMULATION IS NOT AN EFFECTIVE THERAPY
THALAMIC PAIN SYNDROME; REMAPPING OF THE STOMATOSENSORY CORTEX IS SEEN

questions.text: A PATIENT WITH AMPUTED ARM IS PRESENTED TO YOUR CLINIC WITH COMPLAINTS OF PAIN SENSATION IN THE AMPUTATED LIMB. THE LIMB WAS AMPUTATED 2 YEARS BACK DUE TO A ROAD TRAFFIC ACCIDENT. WHAT IS THIS PHENOMENON KNOWN AS AND WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS TRUE STATEMENT
questions.solution:
THE PHENOMENON IS KNOWN AS PHANTOM LIMB SYNDROME AND NOT THALAMIC PAIN SYNDROME

ALL THE STATEMENT ARE TRUE EXCEPT C

THE CORRECT STATEMENT FOR OPTION C IS

SPINALCORD STIMULATION IS AN EFFECTIVE THERAPY

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 171

choices.text: VIT A IS A FAT SOLUBLE VITAMIN WHICH IS ALSO KNOWN RETINOIDS
VIT A DEFICIENCY CONTIBUTE TO BLINDNESS BY MAKING THE EYES DRY WHICH DAMAGES THE CORNEA
THE DEFICIENCY FIRST ALTERS THE CONE FUNCTION AND CAUSE ITS DEGENERATION
ON PROLONGED DEFICIENCY THERE IS DEGENERATION OF NEURAL LAYERS OF RETINA

questions.text: THE PATIENT COMES TO OPD WITH COMPLAINTS OF NIGHT BLINDNESS. ON INVESTIGATION THE PATIENT HAS VIT A DEFICIENCY. THE PATIENT IS FROM LOW SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS. WHICH OF THE FOLOWING IS FALSE IN REGARD TO VIT A DEFICIENCY
questions.solution:
THE DEFICIENCY OF VIT A FIRST AFFECT THE FUNCTION OF RODS AND NOT CONES

DEFECIENCY OF VITAMIN A LEADS TO DEVELOPMENT OF XEROPTHALMIA.

Vitamin A deficiency is most common in Africa and Southeast Asia. It can also occur when the gut can't absorb the nutrient.

Vitamin A deficiency can cause blindness. It can also increase the risk of serious, sometimes fatal, infections. Symptoms include night blindness, dry skin and frequent infections.

Treatments may include supplements and diet changes.

ALL OTHER STAQTEMENTS ARE TRUE

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 183

choices.text: ALL INDIVIDUALS WITH COLOUR BLINDNESS ARE UNABLE TO DIFFERENTIATE ANY COLOURS
IT IS AN INHERITED DISORDER WHICH IS X LINKED DOMINANT
ACHROMATOPSIA IS CLOUR BLINDNESS WITHOUT INVOVEMENT OF VISUAL CORTEX
COLOUR BLINDNESS IS PRESENT IN MALES IF THE X CHROMOSOME HAS ABNORMAL GENE

questions.text: ON GENERAL EXAMINATION OF A PATIENT EYE THE PATIENT IS SHOWN ISCHARA CHARTS IN ORDER TO DIFFERENTIATE THE COLOURS. ON INVESTIGATION THE PATIENT IS DIAGNOSED OF COLOUR BLINDNESS. WHICH IS THE TRUE STATEMENT REGARDING COLOUR BLINDNESS
questions.solution:
THE TRUE STATEMENT FOR OTHER OPTIONS IS AS FOLLOWS

A)SOME INDIVIDUALS WITH COLOUR BLINDNESS ARE UNABLE TO DIFFERENTIATE ANY COLOURS OTHERS CAN DIFFERENTIATE SOME COLOURS

B)IT IS AN INHERITED DISORDER WHICH IS X LINKED RECESSIV

C)ACHROMATOPSIA IS COLOUR BLINDNESS WITH INVOVEMENT OF VISUAL CORTEX

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG193

choices.text: ANOSMIA IN THIS CASE BECAUSE OF DAMAGE TO OLFACTORY NERVE AS A RESULT OF FRACTURE TO CRIBRIFORM PLATE OR THE HEAD TRAUMA
ANOSMIA ASSOCIATED WITH REDUCTION IN TASTE SENSITIVITY
CONGENITAL ANOSMIA IS COMMON AND IS SEEN IN MANY
ANOSMIA CAN ALSO RESULT FROM NASAL BLOCKAGE OR POLYPS

questions.text: A PATIENT WAS PRESENTED TO OPD WITH INJURY TO HEAD DUE TO FALL FROM STAIRS. ALL THE NECESSARY TREATMENT WAS DONE. THE PATIENT ARRIVED 2 WEEKS LATER WITH COMPLAINTS OF ANOSMIA. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS FALSE FOR ANOSMIA
questions.solution:
CONGENITAL ANOSMIA IS RARE IN WHICH THE CHILD IS BORN WITH INABILITY TO SMELL

ALL OTHER STATEMENTS ARE TRUE

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 221

choices.text: PARKINSON IS SEEN AS COMPLICATION OF TAKING ANTIPSYCHOTIC DRUG
PARKINSON IS USUALLY SEEN IN YOUNG NDIVIDUALS
PARKINSON IS DUR TO LOSS OF DOPAMINERGEC NEURONS AND DOPAMINE RECEPTORS
LEVODOPA IS USED WITH CARBIDOPA TO TREAT PARKINSONISM

questions.text: A 80 YEAR OLD MALE PATIENT IS BROUGHT BY HIS SON COMPLAINS OF DIFFICULTY IN WALKING, HAVE TYPICAL PINN ROLL MOVEMENT OF HANDS AND SHOW DYSKINESIA. ON INVESTIGATION THE PTIENT IS DIAGNOSED OF PARKINSON DISEASE. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS FALSE REGARDING PARKINSON
questions.solution:
PARKINSON IS USUALLY SEEN IN MIDDLE ADGED TO ELDERLY INDIVIDUAL

Parkinson's disease is a brain disorder that leads to shaking, stiffness, and difficulty with walking, balance, and coordination.

Parkinson's symptoms usually begin gradually and get worse over time. As the disease progresses, people may have difficulty walking and talking. They may also have mental and behavioral changes, sleep problems, depression, memory difficulties, and fatigue.

Both men and women can have Parkinson’s disease. However, the disease affects about 50 percent more men than women.

One clear risk factor for Parkinson's is age. Although most people with Parkinson’s first develop the disease at about age 60, about 5 to 10 percent of people with Parkinson's have 'early - onset' disease, which begins before the age of 50. Early-onset forms of Parkinson's are often, but not always, inherited, and some forms have been linked to specific gene mutations.

ALL OTHER STATEMENT ARE TRUE

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 247

choices.text: SYMPTOMS USUALLY OCCUR AT 15-25 YEARS OF AGE AND IN HOT CLIMATE
SKIN BECOMES INITIALLY PLAE OR WHITE NUMB OR COLD
VASODIATION IN TIP OF NOSE EAR AND PENIS CAN OCCUR
THE SECOND STAGE IS RUBOR WHICH INCLUDE SWELING AND TINGLLING

questions.text: A PATIENT IS SUFFERING FROM RAYNAUDS PHENOMENON AND THE PATIENT ALSO HAD PAST HISTORY OF SMOKING. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING STATEMENT IS TRUE
questions.solution:
THE TRUE STATEMNET FOR OTHER OPTIONS ARE;

A)SYMPTOMS USUALLY OCCUR AT 15-25 YEARS OF AGE AND IN COLD CLIMATE

C) VASOCONSTRICTION IN TIP OF NOSE EAR AND PENIS CAN OCCUR

D) THE THIRD OR LAST STAGE IS RUBOR WHICH INCLUDE SWELING AND TINGLLING

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th editionPG 264

choices.text: DYSLEXICS HAVE SPECIFICIMPAIRMENT IN REPRESENTATION, STORAGE AND RETRIEVAL OF SPEECH SOUND
PRIMARY DEFICIET IS PERCEPTION OF SHORT OR RAPIDLY VARYING SOUNDS
DEFECT IN MAGNOCELLULAR PORTION OF VISUAL SYSTEM
THERE IS INCREASED BLOOD FLOW IN ANGULAR GYRUS

questions.text: A MOTHER COMES WITH HER SON WITH COMPLAINTS THAT THE CHILD CANNOT READ AND HAVE DIFFICULTY TO SPELL OR TO DECODE A WORD. THE CHILD IS DIAGNOSED OF DYSLEXIA. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING THEORIES IS FALSE REGARDING DYSLEXIA
questions.solution:
ALL A, B AND C ARE THEORIES OF PHONOLOGICAL HYPOTHESIS, RAPID AUDITORY PROCESSING THEORY AND VISUAL THEORY RESPECTIVELY

OPTION D IS NOT A THEORY AND IS ALSO A WRONG STATEMENT

THE TRUE STATEMENT IS THERE IS DECREASED BLOOD FLOW TO ANGULAR GYRUS

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 292

choices.text: THE RESERVOIR FUNCTION OF STOMACH IS MAINTAINED
IF LARGE MEALS ARE EATEN HYPOGLYCEMIA SYMPTOMS OCCUR ABOUT 2 HOURS AFTER MEALS
SYMPTOMS ARE ALSO CAUSED BY RAPID ENTERY OF HYPERTONIC MEALS

questions.text: A 50 YEAR OLD PATIENT HAS UNDERGONE GASTRIC BYPASS SURGERY. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING STATEMENT IS FALSE
questions.solution:
THE RESERVOIR FUNCTION OF STOMACH IS LOST AND IS NOT MAINTAINED

Gastric bypass, also called Roux-en-Y (roo-en-wy) gastric bypass, is a type of weight-loss surgery that involves creating a small pouch from the stomach and connecting the newly created pouch directly to the small intestine. After gastric bypass, swallowed food will go into this small pouch of stomach and then directly into the small intestine, thereby bypassing most of your stomach and the first section of your small intestine.

Gastric bypass is one of the most commonly performed types of bariatric surgery. Gastric bypass is done when diet and exercise haven't worked or when you have serious health problems because of your weight.

ALL OTHER STATEMNETS ARE TRUE

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 500

choices.text: INCREASE LEVEL OF AMMONIA CAUSE HEPATIC ENCEPHALOPATHY
PATIENT INITIALLY CONFUSED AND MAY LEAD TO COMA IS UNTREATED
THERE IS ONLY LOSS OF FUNCTIONAL HEPATOCYTES
ADDITIONAL SUBSTANCES WHICH ARE NORMALLY DETOXIFIED BY LIVER CONTRIBUTE TO MENTAL STATUS CHANGE.

questions.text: A PATIENT HAS LIVER FALIURE WHICH HAS LEAD TO HEPATIC ENCEPHALOPATHY. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS FALSE
questions.solution:
SHUNTING OF PORTAL BLOOD AROUND THE HARDENED LIVER WITH LOSS OF FUNCTIONAL HEPATOCYTES ARE SEEN

Hepatic encephalopathy is an often-temporary neurological (nervous system) disorder due to chronic, severe liver disease. A diseased liver struggles to filter toxins (substances created from the breakdown of food, alcohol, medications and even muscle) from the bloodstream. These toxins build up in the body and travel to the brain. Toxicity affects brain function and causes cognitive impairment.

People with hepatic encephalopathy may seem confused or have difficulty processing their thoughts. Treatments can remove the toxins and reverse the problem. As liver disease progresses, the condition may worsen and become less treatable. Hepatic encephalopathy is also known as portosystemic encephalopathy (PSE).

ALL OTHER STATEMENT ARE TRUE

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th

choices.text: CHARACTERISTIC JERKY EYE MOVEMENT OF THE EYE OBSERVED AT START AND END OF PERIOD OF ROTATION IS NYSTAGMUS
NYSTAGMUS IS USUALLY HORIZONTAL AND CAN BE VERTICAL AS WELL
CALORIFIC STIMULATION IS USED AS TEST T FUNCTION OF VESTIBULAR LABYRINTH
IN CASE OF UNILATERAL LESION IN VESTIBULAR PATHWAY NYSTAGMUS IS ABSENT ON OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE LESION

questions.text: A ACCIDENT PATIENT IS BOUGHT IN EMERGENCY. BLEEDING IS SEEN FROM EAR. ON INVESTIGATION THE PATIENT HAS SUFFERED TEMPORAL BONE FRACTURE.THEPATIENT HAS LOSS VESTIBULOOCULAR REFLEX. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS FALSE STATEMENT
questions.solution:
THE TRUE STATEMENT IS IN CASE OF UNILATERAL LESION I VESTIBULAR PATHWAY NYSTAGMUS IS ABSENT ON SAME SIDE OF LESION

Vestibular nystagmus is a biphasic eye movement with slow and rapid phases of opposite directions. The intensity increases when the eye bulb is directed in the same direction as the fast phase or when fixation is hampered by darkness or eye closure. Nystagmus in which the fast phase changes direction according to the direction of gaze, i.e. gaze (paretic) nystagmus, can be congenital, but is often a result of paralysis of the eye muscles, of infection, intoxication or, if asymmetric in amplitude, of an acoustic neurinoma. Fixation nystagmus, miner's nystagmus, and nystagmus latens, is called optic nystagmus, and is thought to be caused by defects in the fixation mechanism. The main characteristic is that it changes direction if one or both eyes are closed and often interferes with the vestibular nystagmus. In the diagnosis of dizzy patients with optic nystagmus, the examination of the vestibular system must be carried out with other methods than nystagmus recordings.

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG212

questions.text: A PATIENT IS PRESENTED IN CLINIC WITH MUSCLE PAIN N MOVEMENT. ARRANGE THE FOLLOWING STEPS IN SEQUENCE OF INITIATION AND EXECUTION OF MUSCLE CONTRACTION
questions.solution:
THE STEPS FOR INITIATION ANDS EXECUTION OF MUSCLE CONTRACTION IS AS FOLLOWS:

  1. An action potential travels along a motor nerve to its endings on muscle fibers.
  2. At each ending, the nerve secretes a small amount of the neurotransmitter substance acetylcholine.
  3. The acetylcholine acts on a local area of the muscle fiber membrane to open multiple “acetylcholine-gated” cation channels through protein molecules floating in the membrane.
  4. Opening of the acetylcholine-gated channels allows large quantities of sodium ions to diffuse to the interior of the muscle fiber membrane. This causes a local depolarization that in turn leads to opening of voltage-gated sodium channels. This initiates an action potential at the membrane.
  5. The action potential travels along the muscle fiber membrane in the same way that action potentials travel along nerve fiber membranes.
  6. The action potential depolarizes the muscle membrane, and much of the action potential electricity flows through the center of the muscle fiber. Here it causes the sarcoplasmic reticulum to release large quantities of calcium ions that have been stored within this reticulum.
  7. The calcium ions initiate attractive forces between the actin and myosin filaments, causing them to slide alongside each other, which is the contractile process.
  8. After a fraction of a second, the calcium ions are pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum by a Ca++ membrane pump and remain stored in the reticulum until a new muscle action potential comes along; this removal of calcium ions from the myofibrils causes the muscle contraction to cease. We now describe the molecular machinery of the muscle contractile process.

Ref : Guyton and hall textbook of medical physiology 12 th edition PG73

questions.text: SYSTOLIC MURMURS CAN BE SEEN IN ALL EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
IN PULMONARY REGURGITATION, DIASTOLIC MURMURS ARE SEEN, WHEREAS IN ALL OTHERS, SYSTOLIC MURMURS CAN BE SEEN

(REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1229,1230, TABLE 30-2)

questions.text: IN THE ROUTINE CARDIOVASCULAR EXAMINATION OF A PATIENT, THE FOLLOWING FINDING IS SEEN ON ECG. WHAT IS THE MOST PROBABLE DIAGNOSIS?
questions.solution:
IN THE FIRST DEGREE HEART BLOCK, ALL THE ATRIAL IMPULSES REACH THE VENTRICLES BUT THE PR INTERVAL IS ABNORMALLY LONG

WENCKEBACH PHENOMENON IS SECOND DEGREE HEART BLOCK, IN WHICH NOT ALL THE ATRIAL IMPULSES REACH THE VENTRICLES, SO DROPPED BEATS ARE SEEN

STOKES ADAMS SYNDROME IS WHEN THERE ARE SPELLS OF DIZZINESS AND FAINTING IN THIRD DEGREE HEART BLOCK

(REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1198 FIGURE-29-11)

choices.text: HOLTER MONITORING IS USED FOR DIAGNOSIS
CAN BE CAUSED BY ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUGS
INCLUDES BRADYCARDIA, TACHYCARDIA AND BRADYCARDIA - TACHYCARDIA

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS INCORRECT ABOUT SICK SINUS SYNDROME?
questions.solution:
SICK SINUS IS USUALLY SEEN IN INDIVIDUALS OLDER THAN 50, IN WHOM THE CAUSE IS OFTEN NON SPECIFIC SUCH AS SCAR LIKE DEGENERATION. REST ARE CORRECT STATEMENTS.

(REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1199 CLINICAL BOX 29-2)

questions.text: WHILE DOING GENERAL EXAMINATION IN MEDICINE OPD, A RESIDENT NOTICES A FOURTH HEART SOUND IN A PATIENT. WHAT COULD BE THE POSSIBLE PATHOLOGY BEHIND THIS FOURTH HEART SOUND?
questions.solution:
A FOURTH HEART SOUND CAN SOMETIMES BE HEARD IMMEDIATELY BEFORE THE FIRST HEART SOUND WHEN ATRIAL PRESSURE IS HIGH OR THE VENTRICLE IS STIFF IN CONDITIONS SUCH AS VENTRICULAR HYPERTROPHY. IT IS DUE TO VENTRICULAR FILLING AND IS RARELY HEARD IN NORMAL ADULTS.

EXTRA HEART SOUNDS ARE NOT HEARD DUE TO ARRHYTHMIAS

BOTH TRICUSPID STENOSIS AND AORTIC REGURGITATION CAUSE HEART MURMURS AND NOT EXTRA HEART SOUNDS.

(REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1228)

choices.text: IN SYSTOLIC FAILURE, STROKE VOLUME IS REDUCED

questions.text: A 58 Y/O MALE PRESENTED TO THE OPD WITH SYMPTOMS OF BREATHLESSNESS ON EXERTION, FATIGUE ON EXERTION, DIFFICULTY IN BREATHING, DIFFICULTY IN CLIMBING STAIRS AND PALPITATIONS. ON ECHO, THE EJECTION FRACTION WAS NOTICED TO BE 37%. A DIAGNOSIS OF HEART FAILURE WAS MADE WITH FURTHER INVESTIGATIONS. WHAT IS INCORRECT ABOUT THIS CONDITION?
questions.solution:
IN SYSTOLIC FAILURE, STROKE VOLUME IS REDUCED BECAUSE VENTRICULAR CONTRACTION IS WEAK. THIS CAUSES AN INCREASE IN END-SYSTOLIC VENTRICULAR VOLUME SO THAT EJECTION FRACTION FALLS FROM 65% TO AS LOW AS 20%. THE INITIAL RESPONSE IS ACTIVATION OF THE GENES THAT CAUSE CARDIAC MYOCYTES TO HYPERTROPHY AND THICKENING OF THE VENTRICULAR WALL. (CARDIAC REMODELLING)

(REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1239,1240, CLINICAL BOX 30-1)

questions.text: A PATIENT, ON DOING ECG SHOWED VARYING QRS COMPLEX MORPHOLOGY AS SHOWN BELOW. WHAT COULD BE THE DIAGNOSES?
questions.solution:
THE GIVEN ECG SHOWS TORSADES DE POINTES

IT IS A FORM OF VENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA IN WHICH THE QRS MORPHOLOGY VARIES.

(REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 1205,1206 FIGURE 29-15)

questions.text: IF A PATIENT PRESENTS TO THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT, AND FINDINGS SHOW HYPERKALEMIA THAN WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING WOULD YOU NOT EXPECT IN THAT PATIENT?
questions.solution:
THE FIRST CHANGE IN HYPERKALEMIA IS TALL PEAKED T WAVES. AT HIGHER K+ LEVELS, PARALYSIS OF THE ATRIA AND PROLONGATION OF THE QRS COMPLEXES OCCUR, VENTRICULAR ARRHYTHMIAS MAY DEVELOP.

SO, OPTION B IS THE RIGHT ANSWER AS QRS SHORTENING DOES NOT OCCUR.

(REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 1214)

questions.text: WHAT IS THE PULSE IN AORTIC REGURGITATION CALLED AS?
questions.solution:
WHEN AORTIC VALVE IS INCOMPETENT, THE PULSE IS PARTICULARLY STRONG, AND THE FORCE OF SYSTOLIC EJECTION MAY BE SUFFICIENT TO MAKE THE HEAD NOD WITH EACH HEARTBEAT. SO, THE PULSE IN AORTIC REGURGITATION CALLED A CORRIGAN OR WATER-HAMMER PULSE.

(REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 1227)

choices.text: IT IS A CONTROLLED HEAT RADIATOR SYSTEM
IT HELPS IN HEAT LOSS BY SWEATING
IT HELPS IN HEAT LOSS BY BLOOD FLOW
IT HELPS IN INSULATION ALONG WITH SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE

questions.text: A 16 Y/O GIRL WAS EXPOSED TO FIRE AND LOST HER INTACT SKIN BARRIER, WHICH LED TO FLUID LOSS. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS INCORRECT ABOUT SKIN AS A MECHANISM OF BODY TEMPERATURE REGULATION?
questions.solution:
THE BLOOD FLOW IN THE SKIN ACTS AS A MECHANISM OF HEAT TRANSFER AND NOT HEAT LOSS.

REST ARE CORRECT STATEMENTS

(REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:868)

questions.text: IN THE GENERAL EXAMINATION OF A PATIENT WHO CAME TO MEDICINE OPD, THE FOLLOWING READINGS OF TEMPERATURE FROM DIFFERENT SITES WERE OBSERVED. 98.5 F AND 99.5 F. THESE READINGS CAN BE OBTAINED FROM WHICH SITES RESPECTIVELY?
questions.solution:
The average normal core temperature is generally considered to be between 98.0° and 98.6°F when measured orally and about 1°F higher when measured rectally.

(REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:867)

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS NOT A MECHANISM OF HEAT LOSS?
questions.solution:
THE MECHANISMS OF HEAT LOSS WHEN THE BODY IS TOO HOT ARE VASODILATION OF SKIN BLOOD VESSELS, SWEATING, AND DECREASE IN HEAT PRODUCTION. ALSO THE MECHANISMS THAT PRODUCE EXCESS HEAT ARE INHIBITED LIKE - SHIVERING AND CHEMICAL THERMOGENESIS.

VASOCONSTRICTION OF SKIN BLOOD VESSELS IS NOT A MECHANISM OF HEAT LOSS.

(REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:872)

questions.text: A BRAIN SURGEON WAS OPERATING IN X REGION OF THE BRAIN. THIS LED TO FEVER IN THE PATIENT. WHAT COULD THIS REGION 'X' BE?
questions.solution:
When a brain surgeon operates in the region of the hypothalamus, severe fever almost always occurs; rarely, the opposite effect, hypothermia, occurs, demonstrating both the potency of the hypothalamic mechanisms for body temperature control and the ease with which abnormalities of the hypothalamus can alter the set-point of temperature control.

(REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:876).
